Sorry to be a pedantic asshole, but I have a few comments about scientific accuracy in the spirit of good peer review :-)
* a plasma does not contain positively charged molecules. You are going to break the molecules much before you ionize the atoms. There may be neutral molecules hanging around. But the positive particles are most likely ions.
* cold plasma light is mostly due to recombination. It is wildly incorrect to say that the plasma glows because of its temperature. This is true of black bodies that are in thermodynamic equilibrium which is totally not the case in a cold plasma like the one you have here (electrons have huge energies and ions are barely above room temp) (I did the Wien's approx estimate anyhow, and assuming a cold plasma electron temperature of 2eV, you easily have radiation in the ultraviolet, invisible to humans... anyways, I don't think the black body formula applies) In high temperature plasmas you have Breemsthralung radiation from the collisions of electrons with ions and that is very broadband, including the visible. Yet this radiation is very small compared to line radiation which is why you see light here.

One day my friends father decided he did't need his microwave anymore because he was convinced by some dubious advice that it is harmful to irradiate your food so the three of us brought the oven out to the garage and started exploring plasmas in the manner seen here. The first thing we tried was a lit candle. Because we didn't care too much about the oven itself we allowed the balls of plasma to sit against the ceiling of the chamber as they formed.

Although the results we got were encouraging, it was actually not that easy to ignite a plasma directly from a paraffin flame. In addition to the heat damage we noticed some soot had also been deposited on the oven's ceiling.

After that we tried pieces of aluminum foil in various shapes; sheets, crumpled balls, two pieces separated by a small gap, etc. The arcs drawn between aluminum objects were blue-white and very sporadic. They were also confined the surface of the foil, not producing detached plasma.

After that we tried just lighting small pieces of wood or charring larger pieces with a torch this produced the best results. It seems to be easiest to form carbon plasma from materials with a lot of free carbon like charcoal. Water solutions of ionic compunds did not do anything interesting. Dry binary salts may melt but I wouldn't count on plasma.

I have heard that if you heat a section of a piece of glass and place it in the oven before it has a chance to cool the increased conductivity of the hot area will draw the most RF energy and continue being heated further until you eventually melt the entire object. Although I have never done this with a microwave I have accomplished it using an arc drawn from a neon sign transformer. Hot glass and quartz are indeed electrically conductive. I have, in fact, welded broken glass back together by drawing an arc through the crack between them. Starting out with the electrodes on either side of the crack a hot spot is formed at the boundary and then as one is moved along the crack in one direction and the other in the other direction, the entire joint becomes conductive enough to concentrate the current and dissipate enough heat to melt and fuse.

Perhaps wine grapes (vitis vinifera) would work better than traditional concord grapes? (vitis labrusca)
Vinifera grapes are carefully grown in low-moisture climates.  Red grapes in particular have low moisture and very thick skins. A fun experiment: Burn the tip of a cork until it is nice and black. Then put it in a microwave with the burnt end of the cork facing up. Next, put a clear glass overtop the cork, and turn the microwave on for about a minute. Approximately 15 seconds in a big ball of plasma will come out of the cork and remain in the top of the glass for another 15 seconds. It doesn't ruin anything and to redo the experiment, just reburn the cork for another couple seconds. Hours of fun!

I've seen this done with matches, graphite pencil rods, and carbon fiber. The downside of these is they usually require manual ignition. Also, Pyrex seems to work fairly well for containment, especially for preventing the ball from burning through the roof of the oven.

At 2:58 the reason the glass didn't work and the plastic container did, is because the plastic container was on stilts so more oxygenated air could flow in and continue the process. If you do the same thing with a glass container on stilts, the glass won't melt as easily as plastic, and the reaction will continue until either it runs out of oxygen, or it explodes the glass in the microwave.
